channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Two teens arrested in fatal D.C. shooting of college student who interned for GOP lawmaker, U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro says
item.description: Two 17-year-olds have been charged as adults in D.C. Superior Court with first-degree murder while armed, Pirro said at a news conference Friday. A third suspect remains at large. Officials have said Eric Tarpinian-Jachym, who interned for Rep. Ron Estes (R-Kansas), was shot by a group of people who exited a car and opened fire.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Pushing partner to make amends for being an absent dad
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Pushing partner to make amends for being an absent dad

item.title: Our dining critic gave this popular D.C. restaurant zero stars in 2016. Has it improved?
item.description: Tom Sietsema returns to Founding Farmers, one of Washington’s most popular restaurants, for a pulse check.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: U.S. economy picked up 22,000 jobs in August but in June revisions lost jobs for first time since pandemic
item.description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported fewer jobs in downward revisions to June job creation, in a warning sign about President Donald Trump’s tougher tariffs and immigration enforcement. In August, the unemployment rate ticked up to 4.3 percent.

item.title: RFK Jr. hearing. ‘War Department.’ Stephen Miller. Labor market. Gun rules. Jobs for robots. Leaf-peeping. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Caitlin Clark will miss remainder of the WNBA season with injury
item.description: The Indiana Fever star's second season ends with her having appeared in just 13 games. Clark, who helped supercharge interest in the WNBA, has not played since July 15 as she has dealt with groin and ankle injuries. The Fever remains in playoff position but has been decimated by injuries and is not expected to contend for a title.

item.title: Congress not planning a vote to extend Trump’s 30-day D.C. police takeover
item.description: In allowing the Trump administration’s grip on D.C. police to come to an end, Congress closes one chapter in the tussle between local and federal officials vying for control of public safety in the capital. But for now, it appears unlikely that fewer federal agents or camouflage-clad troops will patrol city streets.

item.title: The health risks from plastics almost nobody knows about
item.description: Plastic chemicals, known as phthalates, are everywhere. The Washington Post reviewed more than 50 studies and interviewed more than two dozen scientists, former regulators and industry officials to document how the chemicals are eroding health in unexpected ways.

item.title: Trump to change name of Defense Department to Department of War, a title the White House says more accurately reflects its mission
item.description: The president is expected to sign an executive order Friday to make the change that "will sharpen the focus of this Department on our national interest and signal to adversaries America’s readiness to wage war to secure its interests," according to a document describing the forthcoming order obtained by The Washington Post. It's unclear if he can permanently change the name without legislation from Congress.

item.title: Justice Department issues subpoenas targeting Fed governor Lisa Cook in criminal probe, intensifying Trump’s efforts to oust her
item.description: The White House has accused Cook of falsifying mortgage records to lenders as the Trump administration builds a legal and political case to remove her from the central bank’s board. A federal judge is considering Cook’s request to temporarily block President Donald Trump’s move and keep her on the board, which meets mid-September to consider interest rates.

item.title: RFK Jr. clashed with a GOP senator over the availability of coronavirus vaccines, and other takeaways from his fiery hearing
item.description: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. on Thursday defended his tenure in a roughly three-hour Senate hearing, following upheaval at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and frustration with his approach to vaccines. Here are the biggest takeaways from his testimony.

item.title: Trump administration moves to end European security aid programs meant to thwart Russia, alarming allies and upsetting lawmakers
item.description: The decision would impact hundreds of millions of dollars worth of military aid relied upon by some of NATO’s most vulnerable members.

item.title: Pentagon approves use of Chicago-area Navy base for ICE and possible military operations
item.description: The Pentagon has approved the use of Naval Station Great Lakes, on the outskirts of Chicago, as a staging ground from which the Trump administration can launch operations against undocumented immigrants, said two defense officials familiar with the issue. If deployed, National Guard or active-duty service members could also be housed at the facility.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Drugged by a friend and spinning — in both senses
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Drugged by a friend and spinning — in both senses

item.title: Trump’s Federal Reserve pick plans to keep his White House job while serving on central bank, in unusual threat to Fed independence
item.description: White House economic adviser Stephen Miran, if confirmed to the Federal Reserve, would not resign but would take a leave of absence from the White House, making him the first modern-day Federal Reserve Board member to maintain ties to the White House.

item.title: D.C. attorney general sues Trump over National Guard deployment, calling it an illegal ‘military occupation’
item.description: The lawsuit seeks to force President Donald Trump to withdraw the nearly 2,300 National Guard members stationed in the nation’s capital. D.C. Attorney General Brian Schwalb said the involuntary deployment has infringed on the District’s limited autonomy.

item.title: Senate Democrats call for RFK Jr.’s resignation before he faces a grilling on vaccine policy. Follow live coverage of the hearing.
item.description: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is appearing before senators for the first time after turmoil at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The White House fired CDC director Susan Monarez after she resisted pressure from Kennedy to change vaccine policy, and three top CDC leaders resigned in protest. Calls for Kennedy's resignation have mounted from Democratic lawmakers, public health advocacy organizations and current and former HHS employees.

item.title: This ‘beautiful locale’ is the star of today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Giorgio Armani dies at 91. The designer’s streamlined fashions ruled the red carpet for years.
item.description: Giorgio Armani’s suits and couture gowns were a staple at awards shows. He debuted his first collection at age 40 in 1975, bringing elegance and refinement to the art of the power suit and revolutionizing the way modern men and women dress. “Elegance doesn’t mean being noticed,” he said. “It means being remembered.”

item.title: Vaccine mandates. Trump vs. Harvard. Epstein victims. Abortion pills. Putin hot mic. NFL kickoff. Toilet scrolling. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump administration appeals lower-court ruling that invalidated his tariffs, potentially setting up blockbuster Supreme Court case
item.description: The Supreme Court will now decide whether to hear the administration’s appeal to overturn a ruling that voided most of President Donald Trump’s tariffs on goods from dozens of nations. It could set up a case with huge implications for consumers, businesses, the U.S. economy and global trade.

item.title: House Republicans will seek to permanently overhaul criminal justice in D.C. and further restrict home rule
item.description: One of the draft bills would remove the locally elected D.C. attorney general and replace that official with a presidential appointee. The effort would represent a large step backward in the city's quest to expand its autonomy.

item.title: Texas moves to allow anyone to sue abortion pill prescribers, distributors in effort to stop flow of shipments from blue states
item.description: Gov. Greg Abbott (R) is expected to sign a bill that would allow residents to sue doctors, pill-makers and distributors that supply the drugs to Texans.

item.title: A $1.4 billion Powerball win sounds life-changing. Here’s the catch.
item.description: Sudden wealth might seem like a dream come true, but it can’t shield you from poor choices, says our personal finance columnist.

item.title: U.S. could have stopped boat allegedly trafficking drugs from Venezuela but Trump chose to blow it up, Rubio says
item.description: The strike Tuesday on the vessel in the Caribbean, which U.S. officials said killed 11 people, was intended to send a message, Secretary of State Marco Rubio told reporters. “Instead of interdicting it, on the president’s orders, we blew it up,” he said. “And it’ll happen again.”

item.title: Harvard wins court battle against Trump; administration cannot withhold federal funding, judge rules
item.description: A federal judge in Boston ruled that the Trump administration illegally withheld billions from the Ivy League school for alleged violations of rules against antisemitism. The administration is expected to appeal.

item.title: House Republicans vote to establish new subcommittee to reinvestigate Jan. 6
item.description: Lawmakers slipped a resolution into a rule on the House floor that would establish a subcommittee to revisit the events of Jan. 6, 2021, in which pro-Trump protesters stormed the Capitol aiming to prevent Joe Biden's certification as president. Republicans have complained that the previous probe was biased against President Donald Trump, who has repeatedly denied he lost the 2020 election.

item.title: I resigned from the CDC. Here are three questions for RFK Jr.
item.description: I resigned from the CDC. Here are three questions for RFK Jr.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Wedding opens new front in cold war with late wife’s sister
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Wedding opens new front in cold war with late wife’s sister

item.title: Florida moves to end vaccine mandates to attend school, the first state to do so
item.description: Florida Surgeon General Joseph A. Ladapo’s stances on vaccines and other measures have drawn criticism from public health experts and advocates, who have warned that the overhaul of vaccine policies could cause a resurgence of preventable diseases.

item.title: A high-profile split in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Deportation ruling. Space Command. Epstein files. China parade. ChatGPT controls. Wildfires. SNL cast. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Federal appellate panel rejects Trump’s deportations under Alien Enemies Act
item.description: The appellate panel ruled Tuesday that President Donald Trump unlawfully invoked the centuries-old wartime law to deport Venezuelan migrants, finding no invasion or “predatory incursion” had occurred to justify using the statute to fast-track migrant removals. The decision is widely expected to be appealed to the Supreme Court.

item.title: At an ICE career expo, a Marine veteran and a former MMA fighter are among thousands vying to carry out Trump’s deportation agenda
item.description: The administration is aiming to hire 10,000 new immigration officers next year, drumming up interest through militaristic branding and a signing bonus of up to $50,000 for top recruits. Applicants said they were not deterred by waning public support for the president's hardline approach.

item.title: First batch of Epstein files released by Congress
item.description: The House Oversight and Government Reform Committee released 33,295 pages of documents related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The committee said it was the first in a series of expected releases as a bipartisan group of lawmakers seeks more transparency from the Trump administration on the subject.

item.title: U.S. conducts ‘lethal strike’ on alleged drug vessel in Caribbean, a dramatic escalation as Trump intensifies focus on cartels
item.description: Administration officials said the operation targeted a boat that departed Venezuela and was operated by a “designated narco-terrorist organization.” It appeared to mark the first known time the Trump administration used deadly force to target illicit drug shipments originating in Latin America.

item.title: Federal judge bars Google from exclusive deals for its search engine but says it can keep Chrome in high-profile monopoly case
item.description: Judge Amit P. Mehta rejected prosecutors’ call to break up the Silicon Valley giant as he laid out remedies for his finding last year that it has an illegal monopoly in search.

item.title: D.C. Mayor Bowser welcomes federal law enforcement presence indefinitely, a sign of compliance with Trump
item.description: President Donald Trump’s federalization of the D.C. police force lasts 30 days and is set to expire next week. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser’s plans may quell a showdown over what happens after that deadline passes.

item.title: Trump intends to move U.S. Space Command headquarters from Colorado to Alabama, reversing Biden-era plan
item.description: The announcement, expected from President Donald Trump later Tuesday, marks the latest twist in a years-long partisan battle over the agency’s home.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Grandma’s offhand swipe at adoption gives couple pause
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Grandma’s offhand swipe at adoption gives couple pause

item.title: Trump’s deployment of National Guard troops to Los Angeles violated the law, judge rules in case brought by Gov. Gavin Newsom
item.description: The judge concluded that National Guard troops carried out domestic law enforcement actions, violating federal law. The judge did not order the remaining troops withdrawn but blocked them from certain actions.

item.title: A shakeup comes to this show in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Shutdown watch. Labor Day protests. Israel-Gaza. Gun safety. Green cement. Microplastics. Hat snatcher. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: We ranked 5,700 holidays. Which one's most popular on your birthday?
item.description: The Department of Data found the most (and least) official holidays for every day on the calendar.

item.title: This tracking protects a $600 billion economy. Cutting it is foolish.
item.description: This tracking protects a $600 billion economy. Cutting it is foolish.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: After a move and a baby, neither husband nor marriage is working
item.description: Carolyn Hax: After a move and a baby, neither husband nor marriage is working

item.title: A Labor Day quiz in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your holiday points.

item.title: Afghan quake. Blocked deportation. Trump’s power. Gaza plan. Medicaid cuts. Age verification. Geese trouble. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: More than 600 dead in earthquake in Afghanistan, officials say
item.description: The Taliban-run Interior Ministry said more than 1,500 others were injured after the 6.0-magnitude earthquake struck eastern Afghanistan. Damage and casualties were reported across the region, and the quake was felt in Kabul and neighboring Pakistan.
